rubric.name: Academic Register Consistency
rubric.description: Maintains objective, neutral tone appropriate for technical research papers. Avoids informal modifiers, emotional language, and metaphorical phrasing that would appear in popular science writing.
rubric.exemplary: Zero instances of informal adjectives (e.g., 'hard-won', 'painstakingly'), emotional intensifiers, or extended metaphors (e.g., 'fragmented landscape'). All descriptions use neutral, precise language (e.g., 'this calibration does not persist' rather than 'calibration evaporates').
rubric.proficient: No more than one informal modifier per paragraph; any metaphors are conventional technical terms; tone remains predominantly objective.
rubric.developing: 2-3 instances per paragraph of informal language or creative phrasing that would be appropriate for popular writing but not technical papers; inconsistent register.
rubric.beginning: Frequent use of subjective modifiers, emotional language, or extended metaphors; reads like blog post or popular science article rather than research paper.

rubric.name: Logical Flow and Explicit Connections
rubric.description: Every claim, solution element, or new concept explicitly connects to previously established points. Transitions make logical relationships transparent rather than implicit.
rubric.exemplary: Every paragraph's opening or transition sentence explicitly references prior content; solution elements directly map to stated problems using parallel language (e.g., problem mentions 'opacity and portability', solution addresses both by name); 100% of major claims include backward-looking connective phrases.
rubric.proficient: Most paragraphs connect explicitly to prior content; key solution elements reference their corresponding problems; minor points may lack explicit connection but logical flow remains clear.
rubric.developing: Some paragraphs introduce new concepts without connecting to prior arguments; solution discussion addresses problems implicitly rather than naming them directly; reader must infer relationships.
rubric.beginning: Paragraphs feel disconnected; new concepts appear without justification; solution description doesn't reference the specific problems it addresses; logical jumps require significant reader effort.

rubric.name: Conciseness Without Redundancy
rubric.description: Removes repetitive phrasing and redundant explanations while preserving necessary technical detail. Prefers single precise sentence over multiple restatements of same concept.
rubric.exemplary: Zero instances where the same concept is restated using different words within a paragraph; each sentence introduces new information or relationships; no phrases like 'dual interpretability and portability' followed by separate explanations of both.
rubric.proficient: Minimal redundancy (no more than one restated concept per paragraph); most sentences advance the argument; any repetition serves clear rhetorical purpose.
rubric.developing: Multiple instances of concepts restated with minor word changes; some sentences primarily repackage prior sentences; structure includes both summary statements and detailed explanations of same point.
rubric.beginning: Extensive redundancy with concepts explained multiple times in similar language; low information density; paragraphs feel padded or circular.

rubric.name: Problem-Solution Alignment
rubric.description: Solution descriptions directly address each specific problem dimension introduced earlier. If problem establishes three failure modes, solution explicitly addresses all three using consistent terminology.
rubric.exemplary: Every problem dimension mentioned in problem statement has corresponding solution element in solution paragraph; uses same terminology (e.g., if problem says 'opacity and portability', solution explicitly mentions both terms); 1:1 mapping is transparent to reader.
rubric.proficient: All major problem dimensions addressed in solution; terminology mostly consistent; mapping is clear even if not perfectly parallel.
rubric.developing: Solution addresses some but not all problem dimensions; may introduce solution benefits not connected to stated problems; terminology shifts make mapping less obvious.
rubric.beginning: Solution description feels disconnected from problem; introduces capabilities without showing how they address specific failures; reader cannot easily map solution elements to problems.

rubric.exemplary: Problem/background sections achieve maximum efficiency: zero instances where concepts are restated without adding precision; eliminates explanatory elaboration of established concepts. Solution/system sections provide comprehensive specification: enumerates all key capabilities explicitly; explains how bidirectional features work in both directions; includes synthesis statements that make implications explicit (e.g., 'creates a feedback loop where...', 'Through such refinement processes, the system allows the user to fully understand the rubric, not only in natural language, but also how it is interpreted and used by the LLM in its assistance'). Throughout: adds specifications when they prevent ambiguity or make implicit mechanisms explicit (e.g., 'calibrations achieved in one session do not persist' vs. 'calibrations do not persist'). Each sentence in problem sections advances argument efficiently; solution sections may include multiple sentences elaborating single features for completeness and explaining what understanding or capability they provide.
rubric.proficient: Problem sections minimize redundancy with only occasional restatement; solution sections enumerate most key capabilities with good detail; clarifying phrases added appropriately; most implications stated explicitly; balance between efficiency and completeness mostly context-appropriate.
rubric.developing: Inconsistent elaboration across contexts: either overly concise solution descriptions or redundant problem sections; some capabilities implied rather than enumerated; occasionally sacrifices precision for brevity or vice versa; implications sometimes left implicit; context-appropriateness unclear.
rubric.beginning: Treats all sections uniformly regardless of rhetorical purpose; either pervasively redundant throughout or sacrifices necessary specification everywhere; solution descriptions abstract rather than comprehensive; fails to distinguish between explanatory elaboration (minimize) and mechanism specification (include); implications consistently left for reader to infer.

rubric.description: Solution descriptions directly address each specific problem dimension introduced earlier using consistent terminology. If problem establishes three failure modes, solution explicitly addresses all three by name.

dimensions.label: Parallel language between problem and solution

rubric.exemplary: Every problem dimension mentioned in problem statement has corresponding solution element in solution paragraph using same terminology (e.g., if problem says 'opacity and portability', solution explicitly mentions both terms). 1:1 mapping is transparent to reader without requiring inference.
rubric.proficient: All major problem dimensions addressed in solution; terminology mostly consistent; mapping is clear even if not perfectly parallel.
rubric.developing: Solution addresses some but not all problem dimensions; may introduce solution benefits not connected to stated problems; terminology shifts make mapping less obvious.
rubric.beginning: Solution description feels disconnected from problem; introduces capabilities without showing how they address specific failures; reader cannot easily map solution elements to problems.

The introduction should explicitly connect problems to solutions using consistent terminology, with strong topic sentences that reference prior arguments.

rubric.name: Academic Register Consistency
rubric.description: Maintains objective, neutral tone appropriate for technical research papers. Eliminates modifiers that add emphasis without semantic content (e.g., 'widely', 'fundamental', 'concrete', 'novel'). Replaces metaphorical or abstract phrasing with concrete technical terminology (e.g., 'vanish' → 'do not persist', 'gap' → 'lack', 'conversational interaction' → 'chat interface'). Prefers precise technical terminology even when simpler terms are available (e.g., 'adaptation mechanism' rather than 'conversational memory' when describing the technical system). Avoids subjective or emotional framing (e.g., 'poses a challenge' → 'affects'). Uses formal presentation conventions appropriate to genre (e.g., 'We introduce X' for system contributions). Prefers active voice constructions with clear agents over passive nominalizations (e.g., 'RubricLLM provides mechanisms' rather than 'This externalization requires mechanisms').

dimensions.label: Semantic value of modifiers and intensifiers
Concrete technical terminology vs. abstract/metaphorical phrasing
Preference for precise technical terms over simpler but less accurate alternatives
Active voice with clear agents vs. passive nominalizations

rubric.exemplary: Zero instances of modifiers that add emphasis without semantic content (e.g., 'widely adopted' → 'adopted', 'fundamental problem' → 'problem', 'concrete failures' → 'failures', 'novel paradigm' → 'paradigm'). All metaphors and abstract phrasing replaced with concrete technical terminology (e.g., 'calibrations vanish' → 'calibrations do not persist', 'transparency gap' → 'lack of transparency', 'conversational interaction' → 'chat interface'). Consistently selects more precise technical terminology even when simpler alternatives exist (e.g., 'adaptation mechanism' rather than 'conversational memory', 'inferred preferences' rather than 'learned preferences'). Avoids subjective framing (e.g., 'poses a challenge' → 'affects'). Uses appropriate formal presentation conventions (e.g., 'We introduce X, a system that...' for contributions). Consistently uses active voice with clear agents rather than passive nominalizations.
rubric.proficient: No more than one low-value modifier per paragraph; abstract phrasing limited to conventional technical terms; generally prefers technical precision; predominantly neutral tone; minimal subjective framing; mostly follows formal conventions; primarily uses active voice with occasional nominalizations.
rubric.developing: 2-3 instances per paragraph of unnecessary modifiers or abstract language; inconsistent technical precision; inconsistent register; some subjective or emotional phrasing present; occasionally informal presentation style; mixes active and passive voice inconsistently.
rubric.beginning: Frequent use of intensifiers without semantic content, extended metaphors, or emotional language; uses simpler terms when more precise technical alternatives exist; reads like popular science rather than technical paper; pervasive subjective framing; lacks formal presentation conventions; heavy reliance on passive nominalizations.

rubric.name: Purpose-Before-Mechanism Organization
rubric.description: System capabilities, features, and mechanisms are consistently introduced by first establishing their purpose, goal, need, or the reasoning that motivates them. Purpose/motivation statements explicitly articulate what the feature enables, what problem it solves, why it is necessary, or what collaborative goal it supports before describing how it works. Includes causal/conditional framing that explains WHY features are needed (e.g., 'Because inferred preferences may be incomplete...') not just WHAT they enable. This pattern applies not only to major capability descriptions but throughout solution/system sections whenever mechanisms are introduced. Prefers 'To [accomplish goal], the system [mechanism]' or 'Because [reasoning], the system [mechanism]' over '[Mechanism] does [action]' or abstract nominalizations like 'The [abstraction] requires [mechanism]'.

dimensions.label: Explicit causal/motivational framing explaining why features are needed
Explicit articulation of user-system collaborative goals
Avoidance of abstract nominalizations that obscure purpose

rubric.exemplary: 100% of mechanism descriptions preceded by explicit purpose, goal, or reasoning statements. Uses both infinitive constructions (e.g., 'To ensure alignment in the rubrics' representation, the system supports...', 'To support exploration without commitment, RubricLLM introduces...') and causal/conditional framing (e.g., 'Because inferred preferences may be incomplete, inaccurate, or evolve over the course of a task, RubricLLM supports...'). Purpose and reasoning statements explicitly name collaborative goals, user needs, or motivating conditions. Zero instances of mechanism-first constructions or abstract nominalizations that front-load mechanisms (e.g., 'The externalization of preferences through rubrics requires...').
rubric.proficient: Most mechanism descriptions have purpose or reasoning framing; major capabilities consistently include motivation; minor features may occasionally lead with mechanism; collaborative goals and causal reasoning mostly explicit.
rubric.developing: Inconsistent purpose-before-mechanism structure; some capabilities introduced with purpose statements, others jump directly to mechanisms; causal reasoning sometimes implied rather than stated; collaborative goals sometimes unclear.
rubric.beginning: Predominantly mechanism-first organization; capabilities described by what they do rather than why they matter or why they're needed; abstract nominalizations obscure purpose; reader must infer goals and motivations from mechanism descriptions.

rubric.name: Logical Flow and Explicit Connections
rubric.description: Every claim or concept explicitly connects to previously established points through backward-looking references. Each new concept introduction explicitly names and connects to the specific prior point it builds upon. Transitions make the logical progression transparent rather than requiring inference.
rubric.exemplary: Every paragraph explicitly references prior content using connective phrases (e.g., 'This transparency gap', 'This lack of transparency', 'Despite this apparent personalization', 'This limitation'). Solution elements directly map to stated problems using parallel terminology. 100% of major claims include backward-looking connective language that names the specific prior concept being built upon.
rubric.proficient: Most paragraphs have clear connections to prior content; key solution elements reference corresponding problems; minor points may lack explicit connection but logical flow remains clear.
rubric.developing: Some paragraphs introduce concepts without connecting to prior arguments; solution addresses problems implicitly rather than naming them directly; reader must infer relationships.
rubric.beginning: Paragraphs feel disconnected; new concepts appear without justification; solution doesn't reference specific problems it addresses; logical jumps require significant reader effort.

rubric.name: Topic Sentence Completeness
rubric.description: Every paragraph opens with a topic sentence that fully encapsulates the paragraph's main claim in a self-contained statement. A reader should be able to understand the paragraph's core argument from the opening sentence alone, without needing to read the supporting sentences. Topic sentences should be substantive statements rather than transitional phrases or partial previews.

dimensions.label: Opening enables comprehension of paragraph scope

rubric.exemplary: 100% of paragraphs open with topic sentences that state complete, substantive claims. Reader can understand each paragraph's main point from opening sentence alone. Example: 'Despite this apparent personalization, the adaptation mechanism remains opaque' rather than 'There is also a transparency issue.'
rubric.proficient: Most paragraphs have self-contained topic sentences; occasional opening sentences require body text for full comprehension.
rubric.developing: Many topic sentences are partial or transitional; reader often needs to read multiple sentences to understand paragraph's point.
rubric.beginning: Topic sentences absent or merely transitional; paragraphs lack clear opening statements of their claims.

rubric.name: Precision and Interpretive Synthesis
rubric.description: Balances conciseness with comprehensive specification and interpretive synthesis based on rhetorical context. In problem/background sections, removes repetitive phrasing and explanatory elaboration of already-established concepts. In solution/system description sections, provides comprehensive enumeration of capabilities and explicit specification of how features work, even if this requires additional sentences. Throughout the document, includes synthesis statements that interpret the significance and implications of features, problems, and behaviors—not just describing WHAT they are but explaining WHAT THEY MEAN for users, systems, or the research contribution (e.g., 'This evaluative feedback enables users to directly observe whether the inferred rubric—and the behavior it induces—aligns with their intended goals', 'Without an explicit preference representation, users lack a principled way to understand or steer...'). Adds clarifying specifications throughout when they prevent ambiguity, increase precision, or make implicit consequences/mechanisms explicit. Eliminates structural redundancy like contribution lists that restate body content.

dimensions.label: Explicit articulation of significance, implications, and what features/problems mean for users
Addition of clarifying specifications and explicit mechanism descriptions
Removal of redundant formulations in problem/background sections

Throughout: adds specifications when they prevent ambiguity or make implicit mechanisms explicit. Each sentence in problem sections advances argument efficiently; solution sections may include multiple sentences elaborating single features for completeness while always interpreting what those features enable or mean.

rubric.developing: Inconsistent inclusion of interpretive synthesis—some features explained in terms of significance, others merely described; inconsistent elaboration across contexts: either overly concise solution descriptions or redundant problem sections; some capabilities implied rather than enumerated; occasionally sacrifices precision for brevity or vice versa.

The introduction should explicitly connect problems to solutions using consistent terminology, with strong topic sentences that reference prior arguments.
weighting_rationale: Updated based on user draft edits (from v11)
coaching_notes: The edits reveal two key gaps: (1) The user consistently adds synthesis/interpretation statements that explain the significance and implications of features, going beyond just describing what they do. This is partially captured in 'Precision and Context-Appropriate Elaboration' under 'implication_synthesis' but deserves greater emphasis.
